titleStmt.title: The Garden, or The Contention of Flowers
Poem #12

encodingDesc.p: Transcriptions are encoded in TEI(P5)-conformant XML.

correction.p: Apparent errors are preserved and editorial corrections provided using SIC and CORR tags, but only where the editor conjectures that the original scribe or compositor would have recognized the instance as an error. For example, what according to modern usage is incorrect subject/verb agreement might have been deemed acceptable to a seventeenth-century scribe or compositor. All such instances are treated instead using the ORIG and REG tags. (See below.)

Corrections and annotations made within the scope of the original document either by its original authors, owners, and/or transcribers are noted using ADD tags. These annotations and may be futher explained within NOTE tags, as added by the editors of this digital edition, for display within the apparatus.

normalization.p: Original spellings, abbreviations, and orthography are preserved. Where in the manuscripts a character's status as majuscule or miniscule is ambiguous, the editor has silently chosen one or the other based on context and judgment (i.e., does not register such ambiguity in either the markup or the notes).

quotation.p: Original quotation marks, if any, are preserved.

glyph.glyphName: Handwritten 'ff' ligature, used in handwriting to represent modern F

rdg.seg: The Garden, or The Contention of FlowersIn the manuscript, the title originally continued: “To My Dear Daughter Mistress Anne Pulter, At Her Desire Written”; “Anne” has been crossed out, but is still legible, while “Pulter” is fairly thoroughly blotted out. Anne Pulter, 1635-1666

app.rdg: AE TITLE

rdg.note: In these transcriptions we preserve as many details of the original material, textual, and graphic properties of Hester Pulter’s manuscript verse as we have found practical. Whenever possible, for instance, original spelling, punctuation, capitalization, lineation, insertions, deletions, alterations, spacing between words and lines, and indentation are all maintained; abbreviations and brevigraphs are not expanded; and superscript and subscript representations are retained. See full conventions for the transcriptions here.

The aim of the elemental edition is to make the poems accessible to the largest variety of readers, which involves modernizing spelling and punctuation as well as adding basic glosses. Spelling and punctuation reflect current standard American usage; punctuation highlights syntax which might otherwise be obscure. Outmoded but still familiar word forms (“thou,” “‘tis,” “hold’st”) are not modernized, and we do not modernize grammar when the sense remains legible. After a brief headnote aimed at offering a “way in” to the poem’s unique qualities and connections with other verse by Pulter or her contemporaries, the edition features a minimum of notes and interpretative framing to allow more immediate engagement with the poem. Glosses clarify synonyms or showcase various possible meanings in Pulter’s time. Other notes identify named people and places or clarify obscure material. We rely (without citation) primarily on the Oxford English Dictionary (OED), the Oxford Reference database, and the King James Version (KJV) of the Bible. When we rely on Alice Eardley’s edition of Pulter’s work, we cite her text generally (“Eardley”); other sources are cited in full. The result is an edition we consider a springboard for further work on Pulter’s poetry. See full conventions for this edition here.

Lying in her garden, Pulter finds herself the chosen umpire of a contest among a dozen flowers in this, her longest poem. Before she will choose a winner, she exhorts the disputants to describe their “virtues”—a word encompassing both moral and botanical meanings in a period when plants were key medicinal ingredients. As the garden members readily comply, Pulter is able to show off her extensive knowledge of botany (drawn from classical and contemporary natural histories and gardening manuals), especially its links to mythology, In addition to their role in health care, the plants concern themselves with their “color, beauty, fashion, smell”—alternately, as they speak in turn, vaunting themselves and mocking the other flowers’ grandiose claims each other. As well as a spirited contribution to the poetic genre of the debate, Pulter’s poem quietly critiques a parliamentary system in which representatives devote themselves to self-promotion and mud-slinging more than any larger truth. No wonder the umpire’s discreet choice, in the end, is to cut short this mockery of a parliament—perhaps a particularly happy ending for a royalist like Pulter, whose country’s parliament cut short her king’s life and the monarchy itself, leaving her party to take solace in rural retreats. This garden, ironically, provides little peace or quiet, instead subjecting weary humans to the energetic quarreling that they might go there to escape.

app.rdg: Once in my Garden as a lone I lay
Once in my garden as alone I lay,
Some Solitary howres to paſs away
Some solitary hours to pass away,
My &ff;lowers most faire and fresh w:thin my view
My flowers most fair and fresh within my view,
New Diamon’d watr’d“watr’d” inserted directly above “Diamon’d” over with Aurora’s dew
New diamoneddiamonded; made to glitter like a diamond, watered o’er with Aurora’sgoddess of the dawn’s dew—
Theire names in or^der I er’e long will mention
Their names in order I erebefore long will mention—

Therecorrected from “That”, with initial “e” over “a”; final “t” imperfectly erased; additional “e” crowded into space before next word hap^ened amongst them this contenitionunclear correction of spelling mid-word
There happened amongst them this contention:
Which of them did theire fellowes all excell
Which of them did their fellows all excel
In vertue, Couloure, Bevty, &ff;ashion, Smell
In virtuenot just moral goodness or general superiority but, in this botanical context, beneficial or specifically healing power, color, beauty, fashion, smell;
And mee they choſe for Umpire in this play
And me they chose for umpire in this play.
Then up I roſe, Sad thoughts I laid away
Then up I rose, sad thoughts I laid away,
And unto them I inſtantly Replied
And unto them I instantly replied
That this theire controversy“y” appears crowded into space before next word I’d [?]“would” appears imperfectly erased, with apostrophe and “d” of “I’d” written over “w” decide
That this their controversy I’d decide,
Soe they would Stand to my arbitrement
Soif they would stand to my arbitramentpower to decide for others; decision or sentence of an authority; settlement of a dispute.
They Smileing Anſwer’d they were all content
They, smiling, answered they were all content.
I gave them leave theire virtues to declare
I gave them leave their virtues to declare
That I the better might theire worth compare
That I the better might their worth compare.
And now I doequadruple strike-through humbly doe implore the Ayde
And now I humbly do implore the aid
Of that most Debonare delicious Maide

Of that most debonairgentle; gracious; courteous; affable, delicioushighly pleasing or delightful; affording amusement or enjoyment; characterized by or tending to sensuous indulgence; pleasing to the taste or smell maid,
Louely Erato Crow^n’d with fragrant &ff;lowers
Lovely Eratothe muse of lyric (especially love) poetry and hymns; Greek for “lovely”, crowned with fragrant flowers,
Who with her virgin Sisters Spend their howres
Who with her virgin sisters spend their hours
By Cleare Pereus, Cristall Hippocreen,

By clear PereusPieria was a district on the slopes of Mount Olympus associated with the Muses and with springs that provided poetic inspiration., crystal Hippocrenea fountain on Mount Helicon, where the Muses lived,
Sweet Hellicon or Tempes &ff;lowery green

Sweet Helicon or Tempe’s flowery greenHelicon was a mountain associated with the Muses and with fountains believed to give inspiration to those who drank them. Tempe refers to the valley between Mount Olympus and Mount Ossa, which was dedicated to the cult of Apollo and thus associated with music and beauty.:
&ff;aire Thesbian Ladyes all I aske of you,
Fair Thespianassociated with the dramatic arts (from the sixth-century Thespis, founder of Greek tragedy) ladies, all I ask of you,
Is, that I give to every flower her dueascending straight line beneath,
Is that I give to every flower her due.
&ff;irstin left margin between this line and next: “The Woodbine 1:st” spoake the Double Woodbine wondro:s faire
First spoke the Double Woodbinehoneysuckle, a flowering climbing shrub wondrous fair,
Whose Aromatick Breath perfum’d the Ayre
Whose aromatic breath perfumed the air,
Saying I am confident all that can Smell
Saying: “I am confident all that can smell
Or See will say that I the Rest excell
Or see will say that I the rest excel.
Why am I placed elce ’bout Princely Bowers
Why am I placed else ’bout princely bowersdwellings; chambers; shaded garden retreats,
Shadeing theire Arbours and theyre statly Towers
Shading their arborsgarden features, often shaded and enclosed by intertwined shrubs and lattice work and their stately towers?
I did about [I]Idaliesinitial “I” scribbled out; final “a” altered to “e” Arbour grow
I did about Idalia’sVenus’s arbor grow,
Her bower of Loue, when youthfull Blood did flow
Her bower of love, when youthful blood did flow
In old Anchises veins ^their ^ that“their” in different hand from main scribe; double strike-through on “that” hee did Rest
In old Anchises’sVenus’s lover, father of Aeneas veins; there he did rest
His Rosey Cheeks upon her Lilly brest
His rosy cheeks upon her lily breast,
Whos loue produced the happy Julyan Race
Whose love produced the happy Julian raceThe Roman emperor Julius Caesar claimed to be descended from Aeneas.
Therefore (of all) give mee the chiefest place
Therefore (of all) give me the chiefest place.
Oft hath Diana underneath my Shade
Oft hath Dianagoddess of chastity underneath my shade
To inrich ſome fountaine her unready made
To enrich some fountain her unready madeundressed herself,
Diſcloſeing ^then to my admireing eye
Disclosing then to my admiring eye
Thoſe bevties which who ſoe doth prie
Those beauties which whoso doth pry
Into, (let him) Ô let him) Still beware
Into, let him—O let him—still beware,
Least in Acteons Punniſhment hee Share

Lest in Actaeon’s punishmentThe mythological hunter Actaeon accidentally came upon Diana bathing naked with her maid. To punish him, Diana transformed him into a deer and he was torn apart by his own hunting hounds. he share.
Doe but obſerve the Amezonian Bee
Do but observe the Amazonian beeBees lived in a matriarchy, like Amazons, a mythical group of separatist female warriors.
Com to this Garden, Shee noe flower can See
Come to this garden: she no flowerimplied: no other flower can see
That can with Mell, and Necter her Supplie
That can with melLatin for honey and nectar her supply;
My Cornucopie doth her Satisfie
My cornucopiathe horn of plenty symbolizing fruitfulness and plenty, represented in art as a goat’s horn overflowing with flowers, fruit, and corn doth her satisfy.
Then of precedencie I need not doubt
Then of precedency I need not doubt,
Cauſe I perfume your goeing in and out
’Cause I perfume your going in and outThis line is possibly an allusion to the tradition of growing honeysuckle around the doors of houses (Eardley)..”
Thein left margin, between this line and next: “The Tulip 2d” Tulip to the Woodbine then Replyed
The Tulip to the Woodbine then replied:
I am Amazed at thy infinite Pride
“I am amazed at thy infinite pride.
Dost thou preſume or canst thou once Suppose
Dost thou presume, or canst thou once suppose,
To lead impartiall Justice by the Noſe
To lead impartial Justice by the noseTo lead by the nose was to cause to obey submissively or to guide by persuasion?
Becauſe thou yieldest a pleasſant Spicie Smell
Because thou yieldest a pleasant spicy smell,
Therefore all other flowers thou must excell
Therefore all other flowers thou must excel?
What though thy limber dangling flowers hover
What though thy limberflexible; limp, flaccid, or flabby (physically or morally), dangling flowers hover,
Hideing Som wanton and her wanton lover
Hiding some wanton and her wanton lover—
Though Venus and her Paramore it bee
Though Venus and her paramour it be?
A Micurella bee alone for mee

A maquerella be, alone; for me“A “maquerella” was a term for a female pimp or procuress (see note for this line by Frances E. Dolan, “The Garden” [Poem 12], Amplified Edition). The tulip seems to dismissively order the woodbine to perform that role (to “be” a maquerella) “alone”—that is, to be a maquerella without her (the tulip’s) help—before going on to declare that she refuses the office of pimp. In the manuscript, a blank space after “Micurella,” a lack of punctuation in these lines (as in most of Pulter’s poems), and potentially unusual syntax (as in our proposed editing) makes this passage difficult to parse.,
I Scorn that office as I doe thy Pride
I scorn that officea position with certain duties, here the Woodbine’s hiding of lovers as I do thy pride.
Yet am I in a Thouſand Coulours Died
Yet am I in a thousand colors dyed,
And though my Seed bee Sown a Hundred yeare
And though my seed be sown a hundred year
Yet Still in Newer Coulours I apeare
Yet still in newer colors I appearJohn Gerard describes the tulip’s annual proliferation and variety of its colors (The Herbal or General History of Plants [London, 1633], p. 140).;
Andspaces between lines on this page are greater and hand alters slightly if of other flowers there were none
And if of other flowers there were none,
A Garden might be made of me alone
A garden might be made of me alone,
And floros Mantle might imbroidred bee
And Flora’s mantleFlora is the mythological goddess of flowers and personification of nature's power in producing flowers; a mantle is a cloak or covering. might embroidered be,
As rich as now it is by none but mee
As rich as now it is, by none but me.
That Glorious King that had w:ts heat deſir’d

rdg.seg: That glorious king that had what’s heart desiredThe king is the biblical king of Israel, Solomon, known for his wealth and wisdom; “what’s” signifies “what his.” See Matthew 6:28-29: “Consider the lilies of the field, how they grow; they toil not, neither do they spin: And yet I say unto you, That even Solomon in all his glory was not arrayed like one of these.”

app.rdg: Was never in his Thrown Soe rich attird
Was never in his throne so rich attired
As I, \ not nor \insertion marks and “nor,” directly above “not,” in different hand from main scribe in Such various Coulours drest
As I, nor in such various colors dressed;
Therefore I well may Queen bee of ye Rest
Therefore I well may queen be of the rest.
The Turkiſh Turbants doe inlarg o:r fames

The Turkish turbansIn his Herbal, John Gerard claimed that Turkish people named the tulip because it resembled the headdress that Muslims wore (The Herbal or General History of Plants [London, 1633], p. 146). do enlarge our fames,
And wee are honour’d by A Thousand names

And we are honored by a thousand namesHundreds of tulip cultivars were named in the early seventeenth century as part of the Dutch phenomenon known as “tulipmania” (Anne Goldgar, Tulipmania: Money, Honor, and Knowledge in the Dutch Golden Age [University of Chicago Press, 2008], p. 107).
Which would vain Glory bee here to Rehearſe
Which would vainglory be here to rehearse,
Seing they are known thoughout theymultiple strike-through of “y” Univerſ
Seeing they are known throughout the universe.
Beſides my beuty I haue vertue Store
Besides my beauty, I have virtue storein abundance or reserve;
My roots decay’d Nature doth Restore

My roots decayed nature doth restoreTulips are perennials which restore themselves from their root-like bulbs. Tulip bulbs or roots were also understood to be nutritive: “The roots preserved with sugar, or otherwise dressed, may be eaten, and are no unpleasant nor any way offensive meat, but rather good and nourishing” (John Gerard, The Herbal or General History of Plants [London, 1633], p. 147). In View But This Tulip (Emblem 40) Pulter describes a more technical process by which the tulip’s chemically treated ashes could regenerate the plant itself. If the latter meaning, then “roots” would be a possessive (“roots’”)..
Then let another Speak that can say more
Then let another speak that can say more.”
Thenin left margin: “The Wallflower or Hartseaſe 3d” said the Walflower neither Show nor Smel
“Then,” said the Wallflower, “Neither show nor smell
Alone (by my content) but vertue bears ye bell
(By my content)to my satisfaction but virtue bears the belltakes the first place, has foremost position, or is the best;
&ff;or certainly if Sweetnes bore the Sway
For certainly, if sweetness bore the swayruled or governed; held the highest authority or power,
Then am I Sure to bear the priſe away
Then am I sure to bear the prize away.
If Shew, thyscribbled out ^my flowers are Statly to behold
If show, my flowers are stately to behold:
Som Red, Some White, and Som like burnisht Gould
Some red, some white, and some like burnished gold.
But if yo’l give to vertue all her due
But if you’ll give to virtue all her due,
My worth doth fare excell my Golden hew
My worth doth far excel my golden hue.
Such Rare inherent vertue doth inherrit
Such rare inherent virtue doth inheritobtain; succeed as heir; dwell, take up abode
Within my smell by chearing of Mens spirit
Within my smell, by cheering of men’s spirit,
All turbulent Paſſions I am known to apeaſe
All turbulent passions I am known to appease,
My vulgar nomination being Hearts ease
My vulgar nominationvernacular (i.e., English) name being “Heartsease.”a name applicable at this time to the wallflower as well as pansy
Beſides I doe not for a fitt apeare
Besides, I do not for a fita short period; a sudden and transitory state of activity appear,
As doth the Tulip but I all the yeare
As doth the Tulip, but I all the year
Perfume the Aire to Gardens ad Such grace
Perfume the air, to gardens add such grace
That I without preſumption may take place
That I without presumption may take place
Aboue the Rest, though not like Tulips painted

Above the rest (though not like tulips paintedcolored or ornamented, as with paint; sometimes with derogatory connotations related to pretence and deception; sometimes applied to plants (like tulips) with variegated coloring).
&ff;or beuty never yet made Woman Sainted
For beauty never yet made woman sainted;
Tis vertue doth imortalize theire name
’Tis virtue doth immortalize their name,
And makes an Aromatick Splendent fame
And makes an aromatic, splendentshining brightly; gorgeous, magnificent, beautiful fame.
About this Orb her numerous names Shee Rings
About this orbthe earth herthe Tulip, who “rings” or sounds loudly her multiple names numerous names she rings;
So may Euphratus boast her Thousand Springs
So may Euphratesmajor river in Western Asia, which received water from many sources and rivers boast her thousand springs.
Whilst Nil’s head is Ocult, one ownly name
Whilst Nile’s head is occultThe source of the Nile River in Egypt was not known at this time., one only name
Shee glories in yet of Emergent fame
She glories in; yet of emergent fame
Shee vapouring, brags that shee is Stuck about
Shethe Tulip, vaporingtalking in a blustering or bragging manner; in this context, the word hints at the secondary meaning, “an evaporation of moisture”, brags that she is stuck about
The wretchedsmall blot obscures the “c”; possibly a deliberate cancellation Turbant of ye Pagans“s” cancelled with a blot Rowt

The wretched turban of the pagan routThe Tulip bragged, above, that she is made famous by being associated with the turbans of Turkish people, whom the Wallflower derides as a heathen “rout” (assembly or crowd)..
Such Honor: as diſhonor: I Should Scorn
Such honor as dishonor I should scorn,
And Rather choose as I am to bee worn
And rather choose as I am to be worn
Upon Som lovely modest, virgins breast
Upon some lovely modest virgin’s breast,
Where all the graces doe triumphant Rest
Where all the Gracesthree goddesses who represented intellectual pleasures: beauty, grace, and charm do triumphant rest.”
Thein left margin “The Lilly 4:th” lilly Smiled, and Said Shee did admire
The Lily smiled and said she did admire
The Walflowers boldnes, and her bold deſire
The Wallflower’s boldness and her bold desire.
Becauſe Shee breaths a Suffocateing fume
“Because she breathes a suffocating fume,
Must Shee (Ô Strange) aboue the rest peſume
Must she (O strange!) above the rest presume?
I am amazed at her arrogance
I am amazéd that“at” in the manuscript her arrogance,
Proceeding from her Sorded Ignorance
Proceeding from her sordid ignorance
Of others worth makes her extoll her own
Of others’ worth, makes her extol her own;
&ff;or noble vertues trust mee Shee has non
For noble virtues, trust me, she has none.
Her colour doth proclaim her Jealoſie
Her color doth proclaim her jealousyThe Lily argues that the Wallflower’s color, yellow, is associated with jealousy.,
But I’m an Embleme of pure Inocie
But I’m an emblem of pure inno’cyshortened form of “innocency”.
Spotles my thoughts as Spotles are my leaves
Spotlessfree from blemish or (figuratively) sin, guilt, or disgrace my thoughts, as spotless are my leaves,
While Chastitie her Lover ne’r deceives
While ChastityThe lily was the emblem of chastity and purity. her lover ne’er deceives;
And what I wonder were a Virgins due
And what, I wonder, were a virgin’s due,
Had not her Skin my Lillies lilly Hue
Had not her skin my lily’s lily hue?
Even as the Woodbine wittyly exprest
Even asJust as the Woodbine wittily expressed
When Shee compar’d mee to Idalias breast
When she compared me to Idalia’s breast.
White are my leaves as Albians Snowey Cliffe
White are my leaves, as Albion’s snowy cliffAlbion is an alternative name for England, where the White Cliffs of Dover are located (albus is Latin for white).,
Or higher Alps, or highest Tenerif,

Or higher Alps, or highest TenerifeMt. Blanc (or “White Mountain”) is the highest mountain in the Alps range of Central Europe. Tenerife, the largest of the Canary Islands, off West Africa, is dominated by Mt. Teide, Spain’s tallest peak.;
White as the Swans on sweet Hibernias Streams
White as the swans on sweet Hibernia’s streamsHibernia is the Latin name for Ireland (where Pulter was born).,
Or Cinthias bright, or Delias brighter beames

Or Cynthia’s bright, or Delius’s brighter beamsCynthia is goddess of the moon and Delius of the sun. “The Oyster and the Mouse” (Emblem 48) refers to Apollo and Diana as the “Delian twins”; throughout the manuscript, Pulter refers to the male sun god (from Delos) as “Delia,” a name that conventionally identifies the female moon goddess; we have changed to Delius here for clarity..
&ff;or white all other Colours doth excell
For white all other colors doth excel
As much as Day doth Night or Heaven doth Hell
As much as day doth night, or Heaven doth Hell.
&ff;or it is chiefly Heavens privation
For it is chiefly Heaven’s privation
Makes men in a Hell of desperation
Makes men in a hell of desperation.
What are the horrid gloomey Shades of Night
What are the horrid gloomy shades of night
But the departure of all quickning Light
But the departure of all-quick’ninglife-giving; accelerating light?
And what are coulours reaſon Sa’s not I
And what are colors? Reason says, not I,
Nothing but want of my white puritie
Nothing but want of my white purityIn answer to the preceding question, Reason replies that colors are nothing but the lack (“want”) of whiteness..
I here could Iappears crowded into space between surrounding words, possibly in different hand from main scribe brag but ^will not of the feast
I here could brag, but will not, of the feast
The Percians [H?d]two or three letters, starting with “H,” scribbled out^ make this Hono:rs mee ye least
The Persians makeThe Persian duke of Shiraz held an annual feast of lilies lasting 180 days (Eardley).: this honors me the least
Of all the Rest: of vertues I may boast
Of all the restall her other honors. Of virtues I may boast,
&ff;or if my Roots they doe but boyl or Roast
For if my roots they do but boil or roast,
And them to pestilenciall Sores apply
And them to pestilentialplague-infected sores apply,
Probatum est, it cures them instantly
Probatum estThis Latin phrase (“it is proven”) was commonly attached to medical recipes, indicating that they were effective.: it cures them instantly.
But my Antagonest here of the Wall
But my antagonist here of the wallthe Wallflower
In such a time’s away thrown flowers & all
In such a time’s away thrown, flowers and all.”
Atin left margin: “The Rose 5:th” this ye Blood flush’d in ye Roſes face
At this, the blood flushed in the Rose’s face
To heare the Lilly Speake in her diſgrace

To hear the Lily speak in herThe phrasing is ambiguous: the Rose can mean that the Lily has disgraced herself in making prideful and false claims, or that the Lily has dishonored the Rose by declaring superiority over other flowers. disgrace.
As Shee then Said, whoſe pride was grown So high
As she then said, “Whose pride was grown so high
That Shee preſumes to boast Virginitie
That she presumes to boast virginity,
Though Scorn’d by all, dareing to Shew her face
Though scorned by all? Daring to show her face
And plead precedencie and I in place
And plead precedency (and I in place)The sense here continues from the last sentence: the rose castigates the lily, universally scorned, for claiming superiority when the rose is present. ,
When in each lovly Maid and Cloris cheek
When in each lovely maid and Chloris’sChloris is the goddess of flowers and spring. Here the Rose refers to the common poetic description of beautiful women as having cheeks like roses. cheek
I conquer her, her leaves I know are sleek
I conquer her? Her leaves I know are sleek,
And Soe are mine, shee brags ^on Such a fashion
And so are mine! She brags on such a fashion
As if Light, Vertue, Joy, were but privation

As if light, virtue, joy, were but privationThe rose critiques the lily’s claim that her whiteness–which the rose sees as a lack or “privation” of color–embodies the ideals of light, virtue, and joy.,
As if an unwrit Volume were the best
As if an unwrit volume were the best,
Before Heavens loue were in the leaves expre’st
Before Heaven’s love were in the leaves expressed.
I’me Sleighted now but in the former Age
I’m slightedtreated with indifference or disrespect now, but in the former age
I conſecrated was to Epic^rage
I consecrated was to epic’rageepicureanism, the philosophy of Epicurus, a Greek thinker who held that the senses provided the sole criterion of truth and who saw pleasure as the highest human goal;
When liber paters wine and wit ore flowes
When Liber Pater’sItalian god of wine and fertility (associated with Bacchus) wine and wit o’erflows,
Non dares to speak but underneath the Roſe
None dares to speak but underneath the rosean expression for being sealed in silence, or sub rosa (Latin), sometimes connected to the secrecy of love.
And certainly my flowers were in Request
And certainly my flowers were in request
When those Heroyick houſes in theire crest

When those heroic housesthe warring aristocratic “houses” (families) of York and Lancaster in England, whose symbols were, respectively the white and red rose, and whose fifteenth-century battle for power was called “The War of the Roses” in their crest
Did Stick my Roſe; York gloryed in the white
Did stick my rose: York gloried in the white;
Great Lancaster did in the Red delight
Great Lancaster did in the red delight.
But as my fame, Soe it increaſ’d my woe
But as my fame, so it increased my woe
To see or: feilds with pricely blood or’e flow
To see our fields with princely blood o’erflow.
Ney more thee Orient Kingdoms to my praiſe
Nay more, the Orient kingdoms to my praise
In Hono:r of my Birth keepe fowerteen dayes
In honor of my birth keep fourteen daysunidentified ritual or custom,
And in Damasckusthe “c” is crowded between the “s” and “k” yearly they diſtill
And in Damascus yearly they distill
As much Roſewater as will drive a Mill

As much rosewater as will drive a millDamascus was a production center for rosewater, a staple in foods and medicines. Robert Burton writes of “those hot countries, about Damascus, where ... many hogsheads of Rosewater are to be sold in the market, it is in so great request with them” (The Anatomy of Melancholy [Oxford, 1621], p. 309)..
Doe but observe when as the virgin crew
Do but observe when as the virgin crew
Comes to this Garden (newly Pearl’d w:th Dew)
Comes to this garden (newly pearled with dew)
To make their Anadems they ^fill their laps
To make their anademsflowery wreaths for the head: they fill their laps
With other flowers; betwixt their Snowey paps
With other flowers; betwixt their snowy papsbreasts
I am triumphant, on that Ivory Throne
I am triumphant. On that ivory throne
I Sit envied of all uſurp’d of none
I sit envied of all, usurped of none.
Somtime I Slide into that milkey vale

(Or Plinyancient Roman author of a famous work of natural history lies) doth propagate my racePliny writes that white lilies propagate at times “by means of a certain tearlike gum” (Book 11, Chapter 11, in The Natural History, trans. John Bostock, Perseus Digital Library Project)..

There by the lapséd Jews I am adoredEzekiel 8:14 mentions heathen women lamenting at the festival of Thammuz (also Tammuz), mentioned in the next line; this was a Sumerian, Babylonian and Assyrian god identified with Adonis and celebrated as signifying seasonal rebirth. Syrian festivals for him coincided with the river’s annual turning red with mud, which women would lament as commemorating the god’s wound.,
